title: How to Use Rosehips for Health

steps.headline: Harvest fresh rosehips from a rose bush.
steps.description: Rosehips are the seed pods on a rose bush. They form after a rose blossom blooms and dies. Don't deadhead your rose bush because then the rosehips won't form. Instead, wait until the flower falls off on its own, which will reveal the rosehip. Then, pull off the rosehips and place them in a clean bowl. Rose hips are ready when they're red or orange in color. Don't use a rosehip that looks decayed or that's been damaged by birds or insects. While you can harvest rosehips as soon as they form on your rose bush, they'll taste the best if you harvest them after the first frost. That's because the cold will increase the sweetness of the rosehips. If you don't own a rosebush, ask to harvest rosehips from someone you know who has a rose bush. Alternatively, look for rose bushes in the wild. It's best to use rosehips that you know weren't treated with pesticides.Variation: You may be able to find fresh rosehips at your local Farmers Market or health food store.

steps.headline: Put 12 fresh rosehips into a pot with 2 ⁄2 cups (590 ml) of water.
steps.description:
Rinse the rosehips before you put them in the pot and cover them with cold water. The water should completely cover the rosehips.Did You Know? Using fresh rosehips instead of dried rosehips will preserve more of the plant's vitamin C.

If you'd like stronger-tasting tea, add 3 extra rosehips.

steps.headline: Bring the water to a boil for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the burner to high and set a lid on the pot. When you see steam escape from under the lid, wear oven mitts to take the lid off. Then, set a timer and let the tea boil for up to 5 minutes. The water should turn rose-colored as the rosehips boil.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and mash each rosehip in the water.
steps.description: You can use a potato masher or the back of a fork to push on each softened rosehip so they pop open. This will release more flavor into your tea. Be careful not to splash the hot water onto your skin as you smash the rosehips.

steps.headline: Steep the tea for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Keep the burner turned off and leave the smashed rosehips to steep in the hot water. The tea will cool as it steeps, so you'll need to turn the heat on to low a few minutes before you're ready to enjoy it.

steps.headline: Strain the tea through a filter and pour it into cups.
steps.description: Set a coffee filter into a fine-mesh strainer and place it over a teapot. Slowly pour the rosehip tea into the filter so it catches seeds and solids. Then, discard the filter and pour your beautiful tea into serving cups. You can flavor the tea with honey, sugar, or lemon if you prefer. Since there's no caffeine in this tea, which technically makes it a tisane or infusion, you can drink it throughout the day.

steps.headline: Avoid taking rosehip supplements if you're pregnant or nursing.
steps.description: Although rosehips are generally considered to be safe, more research is needed to prove whether or not it's safe to use during pregnancy. If you're pregnant or nursing, don't take rosehip supplements or powders. It's fine to eat foods that contain rosehips since these contain only small amounts of the plant.

steps.headline: Take a daily rosehip supplement to get more vitamin C in your diet.
steps.description: Rosehips are high in antioxidants and vitamin C, which you can get from taking a rosehip capsule or tablet. Most supplements contain 550 mg of rosehips and you'll need probably need to take 1 capsule 3 times a day or as specified by the manufacturer. Vitamin C is great for your immune system and is a natural antioxidant.Tip: Many manufacturers recommend that you take the supplement with water or meals. You might see rosehip supplements labeled "rosa canina."

steps.headline: Add rosehip powder to your diet in order to strengthen your bones.
steps.description:
Studies show that taking 1 to 2 teaspoons (5 to 10 g) of rosehip powder a day might prevent bone loss and help your bones create more collagen so they're stronger. To use rosehip powder, stir it into:
Yogurt or a smoothie
Water or juice
Ice cream
Granola

steps.headline: Use rosehip oil to manage arthritis pain and inflammation.
steps.description: If you suffer from osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, taking rosehips may relieve pain and inflammation without the risk of developing ulcers. Purchase or make your own rosehip oil and rub a coin-sized amount onto your skin or joints. If you're making your own rosehip oil, you'll need to store it in the refrigerator since it doesn't contain preservatives.

steps.headline: Cook with rosehips to get more rosehips in your diet.
steps.description: If the idea of taking a supplement or drinking rosehip tea doesn't appeal to you, try making rosehip jam! You can also make a syrup to pour over baked goods or add rosehips to muffins and bread. If you'd like your rosehip foods to be naturally sweeter, look for recipes that include apples or raisins.
